abstract.text: We review the first measurements of the CKM angle from LHCb. These measurements have been performed with b-hadron decays dominated by b ! u and b ! c tree-level amplitudes, from which can be determined without theoretical uncertainties. Precision is achieved by averaging results from B ! Dh

body_text.text: Introduction
The measurement of the CKM angle

] of the Unitarity Triangle (UT) is an important goal of the LHCb physics programme. The angle plays a unique role among all CP-violating parameters because it can be determined using pure tree-level decays of B mesons without theoretical uncertainties. As tree-level measurements are expected to be insensitive to physics beyond the Standard Model (SM), the value of determined in this way provides an important SM benchmark against which other measurements, more likely to be a↵ected by phyics beyond the SM, can be compared. The power of this approach to new physics searches relies on precise measurements. Despite results from B-factories and Tevatron have improved considerably the knowledge of the UT angles and sides, is still the least-well determined angle, with an experimental uncertainty from treelevel measurements of 9 12 [1,2]. This precision can be significantly improved with large datasets at LHCb.

The angle can be measured in a theoretically clean way by exploiting the interference between b ! u and b ! c tree-level transitions in decays of b-hadrons with a charm meson in the final state. Many B ! DH decays are suitable, where D indicates a D 0 or D 0 and H is the bachelor hadronic system, e.g., a kaon or a K ⇤0 in the most sensitive measurements.

The first constraints on at LHCb have been obtained from time-integrated measurements of charged B mesons [3], which do not require flavour-tagging, therefore can exploit the full statistical power of the large bb production cross-section in pp collisions at the LHC. In these measurements is determined from the interference between B + ! D 0 h + and B + ! D 0 h + (h = K, ⇡) 1 , where D 0 and D 0 decay to a common final state. In addition to , the interference depends on two B hadronic parameters, a e-mail: stefania.ricciardi@stfc.ac.uk 1 Charge-conjugation is implied throughout this paper unless otherwise stated.

which are known as B , the relative strong phase between the two B decay amplitudes, and r B , the relative ratio of the suppressed over the favoured amplitude. Di↵erent methods exist to determine these and other D hadronic parameters from data without theoretical uncertainties. Three types of D decays have been studied by LHCb, corresponding to three well-established methods to determine and all the unknown parameters: the GLW method [4,5]), which uses decays to CP eigenstates (D ! K + K and D ! ⇡ + ⇡ ); the ADS method [6]), which uses decays to quasi-specific flavour eigenstates (D ! K + ⇡ and D ! K + ⇡ ⇡ + ⇡ ); and the GGSZ method [7], which uses self-conjugate three-body final states (D ! K 0 S ⇡ + ⇡ and D ! K 0 S K + K ). Time-integrated measurements can also be performed with neutral b-hadrons when the concerned decay is selftagged. This is the case of B 0 ! DK ⇤0 , where the charge of the kaon from the K ⇤0 ! K + ⇡ decay identifies the flavour of the neutral B meson. Preliminary results on these decays have recently been presented by LHCb [8].

Measurements with charged B decays 2.1 ADS/GLW results

body_text.section: Measurements with charged B decays 2.1 ADS/GLW results
body_text.text: Charged B decays to Dh + with D ! h + h , where each h can be a kaon or a pion, are characterised by an easy topology and can be reconstructed with relatively high efficiency at LHCb [10]. A combined GLW and ADS analysis is performed using the CP-even eigenstates D ! h + h and the quasi-flavour-specific eigenstate D ! K + ⇡ . The observables with sensitivity to are constructed by taking ratio of yields, so that many systematic uncertainties cancel. CP asymmetries and ratios of partial widths of suppressed over favoured modes are determined with a simultaneous fit to the B mass of all 16 possible final states. The expected CP asymmetries in the B + ! D⇡ + channels are smaller than the corresponding ones in the B + ! DK + channels, since the value of r B , which controls the size of the CP interference, is naively ⇠20 times smaller, but the large yields in the B + ! D⇡ + channels help constrain the mass shape in the fit.

body_text.section: Measurements with charged B decays 2.1 ADS/GLW results
body_text.text: Among the results, we note the first evidence of nonzero CP asymmetry, A CP , between B ! DK and B + ! DK + decays with D ! K + K , A CP (KK) = 0.148±0.037± 0.010, and D ! ⇡ + ⇡ , A CP (⇡⇡) = 0.135 ± 0.066 ± 0.010, which combined give 4.5 significance for CP violation in these modes. No significant asymmetry is found in the corresponding B + ! D⇡ + modes.

body_text.section: Measurements with charged B decays 2.1 ADS/GLW results
body_text.text: Another important result of this analysis is the first observation of the rare ADS mode, B + ! D(K ⇡ + )K + , with more than 10 significance. This mode is particularly sensitive to since the two interfering amplitudes (i.e., the favouredb !c transition, followed by a doubly-Cabibbosuppressed D decay, and the suppressedb !ū transition, followed by the Cabibbo-favoured D decay) have similar size, hence can give large asymmetries. The invariant mass distribution of both the suppressed B + ! DK + and B + ! D⇡ + modes, separated by B charge, are shown in Fig. 1. There is evidence for large CP asymmetry in the B + ! DK + mode, A K ADS (K⇡) = 0.52 ± 0.15 ± 0.02, and a hint of asymmetry in the B + ! D⇡ + , A ⇡ ADS (K⇡) = 0.143 ± 0.062 ± 0.011. Further results on GLW and ADS observables are given in Ref. [10].

body_text.section: Measurements with charged B decays 2.1 ADS/GLW results
body_text.text: More recently, LHCb has published measurements of CP observables using the B + ! D(K ⌥ ⇡ ± ⇡ ⌥ ⇡ ± )h + decay [11]. The ADS observables share the same B decay parameters (r B , B ) with B + ! D(K ⌥ ⇡ ± )h + , but di↵erent D decay parameters, therefore, the inclusion of this decay adds complementary information, not just additional statistics, to the determination of from a combined fit to all the modes. We note that the suppressed ADS modes in both the B + ! DK + and B + ! D⇡ + channels have not previously been observed. In addition to the first observation of these modes at LHCb, with a significance which exceeds 5 and 10 , respectively, we mention a hint of CP asymmetry, A K ADS (K3⇡) = 0.42 ± 0.22 in the B + ! DK + mode. The asymmetry in the B + ! D⇡ + mode is measured to be A ⇡ ADS (K3⇡) = 0.13 ± 0.10.
GGSZ results

The GGSZ method exploits the di↵erent interference pattern, for B + ! DK + and B ! DK decays, in the D ! K 0 S h + h Dalitz plot. This is a powerful method which dominates the sensitivity on at B-factories, thanks to the rich resonance structure and the relatively large branching fraction of the D ! K 0 S ⇡ + ⇡ decay. The determination of requires external information on the variation of the D ! K 0 S h + h amplitude phase over the Dalitz plot, D . A model-independent approach is taken in the first LHCb analysis with this method, which uses the CLEO [12] measurements of D in bins of the Dalitz plot. The cartesian coordinates x ± = r B cos ( B ± ) and y ± = r B sin ( B ± ), are then extracted from a simultaneous fit to the B ± mass distribution in each Dalitz-plot bin. The LHCb average

Precision on is achieved by combining all the results obtained with charged B decays that are mentioned in Sect. 2. A frequentist approach has been used by LHCb [3]. The combination uses additional inputs from CLEO [15] for the D ! K + ⇡ and D ! K + ⇡ + ⇡ ⇡ + decay parameters. The recent evidence for a di↵erence in the CP asymmetries in D ! K + K and D ! ⇡ + ⇡ , a dir CP = ( 0.656±0.154)⇥ 10 2 [16], is taken into account in the combination, however it has only marginal e↵ects on the final results.

Measurements with B 0 decays

The use of B 0 ! DK ⇤0 decays is particularly interesting because r B for this mode is naively a factor ⇠ 3 larger than the analogous ratio for B + ! DK + decays, hence the system can exhibit large CP-violating e↵ects. The invariant mass distribution of the selected D(K + K )K ⇤0 candidates is shown in Fig. 7. In addition to the B 0 mass peak, also a peak at the B 0 s mass is observed. The B 0 s ! DK ⇤0 decay is used as control channel, as no large CP violation is expected in this mode. The CP asymmetries, computed from the e ciency-corrected signal yields, are found to be  for B 0 and B 0 s , respectively. Other results for the GLW observables can be found in Ref. [8]. These are the first measurements of CP asymmetries in B 0 and B 0 s to DK ⇤0 decays with the neutral D meson decaying into a CP-even final state. With more data, improved measurements of these and other quantities in B 0 ! DK ⇤0 decays will set important constraints on . The first preliminary measurement of time-dependent CP violation observables in B 0 s ! D ⌥ s K ± decays has recently been reported by LHCb [9]. This measurement is unique to LHCb, because it is the only existing experiment which has accumulated a su ciently large sample of B 0 s decays and is able to distinguish the rapid B 0 s -B 0 s oscillations (thanks to its excellent proper-time resolution and the boost of the B 0 s mesons at LHC). Additional ex-  perimental challenges for this measurement are related to the e ciency of the flavour-tagging algorithms and the determination of the proper-time acceptance. The LHCb results include both untagged and flavour-tagged candidates. Untagged events carry additional sensitivity to the weak phase since the decay width di↵erence in the B 0 s system, s , is sizeably di↵erent from zero. The mass distribution of the total sample is shown in Fig. 8, and the propertime distribution in Fig. 9, where the contribution of all the di↵erent components to the combined sample can be appreciated. The results on the CP observables can be found in [9]. The correlations between the systematic uncertainties have an important impact on the determination of 2 s and require further studies. No attempt has been made at this stage to derive confidence intervals for the weak phase.
Conclusions and prospects

Using 1 fb 1 of the 2011 dataset, LHCb obtains = 71.1 + 16.6 15.7 ( ) by combining GLW, ADS and GGSZ B + ! DK + observables. This result is in good agreement and has comparable precision to the combined results recently published by BaBar [17] and Belle [18]. Time-integrated measurements with B 0 ! DK ⇤0 and time-dependent measurement with B 0 s ! D ± s K ⌥ decays are also showing promising results. Statistical uncertainties are the dominant uncertainties in all these measurements. Precision on is expected to improve significantly in the next years using these and other tree-level decays, which will become accessible with larger datasets. It has been estimated that sub-degree precision can be achieved with 50 fb 1 at the proposed LHCb upgrade using a combination of several decay channels [19].
